M.G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to M.G.L. c. 212, § 4, which provides the Superior Court with original jurisdiction over civil actions for damages greater than $50,000 or equitable relief.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the Property is located in Hampden County, and the acts or omissions giving rise to this complaint occurred within this jurisdiction.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: Under Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14, a landlord’s deliberate or negligent failure to remedy conditions that substantially interfere with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, entitling the tenant to recover compensatory damages.

Dartmouth v. Silva, 325 Mass. 401 (1950).proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages for Defendant’s violation of her right to quiet enjoyment pursuant to M.G.L. c. 186, § 14 and related case law, including Dartmouth v. Silva, 325 Mass. 401 (1950), which holds that tenants are entitled to the uninterrupted enjoyment of their premises.
Dartmouth v. Silva, 325 Mass. 401 (1950).support_reasoning: The opinion has nothing to do with landlord‑tenant relations, quiet enjoyment, or G.L. c. 186, § 14. It addresses a town’s right to enjoin landowners from obstructing a natural watercourse that causes flooding of public ways, framed as a public nuisance issue. It therefore cannot be cited as authority that residential tenants are entitled to uninterrupted enjoyment of leased premises or for statutory quiet enjoyment damages.
Dartmouth v. Silva, 325 Mass. 401 (1950).relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff grounds its right to relief on the existence of a nuisance. We construe the findings of the master as establishing that the brook which ran through the land of the defendants was a natural watercourse… The obstruction of a watercourse so as to cause the water to flow over a highway is a public nuisance… A town is under a duty to keep its ways in repair and is liable to travellers injured by reason of a breach of that duty."
